qas.question: What was kermes lake made from?
What was madder lake made from?
What did Renaissance painters call the pigment made from cochineal?
During what century did carmine start to see use?
What would to the carmine pigment if not used diligently?
What was used by all painters?

plausible_answers.text: Rembrandt, Vermeer, Rubens, Anthony van Dyck, Diego Velázquez and Tintoretto

qas.question: Who were the great painters of the 15th century?

plausible_answers.text: Thomas Gainsborough, Seurat and J.M.W. Turner.

context: The painters of the early Renaissance used <b5_0>two traditional lake pigments<b5_0/>, made from mixing dye with either chalk or alum, kermes lake, made from <a0_0>kermes insects<a0_0/>, and madder lake, made from the <a1_0>rubia tinctorum plant<a1_0/>. With the arrival of cochineal, they had a third, <a2_0><b8_0>carmine<b8_0/><a2_0/>, which made a very fine crimson, though it had a tendency to <a4_0>change color<a4_0/> if not used carefully. It was used by almost all the great painters of the <a3_0>15th<a3_0/> and 16th centuries, including <b6_0>Rembrandt, Vermeer, Rubens, Anthony van Dyck, Diego Velázquez and Tintoretto<b6_0/>. Later it was used by <b7_0>Thomas Gainsborough, Seurat and J.M.W. Turner.
